author: WMNdellis
title: Westcountry home and gardens used as set for BBC drama opens its...
text:
Westcountry home and gardens used as set for BBC drama opens its doors to the public By WMNdellis | Posted: October 01, 2015 autumn colours Westcountry home and gardens used as set for BBC drama opens its doors to the... X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
A picturesque Westcountry Victorian house and garden, used as a filming location for a the new BBC drama The Coroner, will open to the public this autumn. 
Lukesland, which has 24 acres of gardens and is just north of Ivybridge, opens from from 11am – 5pm on Sundays and Wednesdays from October 4- November 15. 
The current spell of fine dry weather is ideal for autumn colour, so Lukesland’s unusual collection of trees and shrubs can be expected to offer a wonderful display of reds and golds, reflected in the ponds and pools of the Addicombe Brook, which runs off Dartmoor through the garden. 
The Howell family, who live at Lukesland, serve up seasonal soups and cakes in the tea room, by a log fire. And children can enjoy a fun nature trail around the grounds, exploring the many secret paths and bridges in this delightful woodland valley. Related content New BBC One series The Coroner on location in Devon 
Dogs are also welcome on a lead. 
As well as the garden openings, the interior of Lukesland is going to be on display this autumn, as the setting for an episode of the new BBC crime drama ‘The Coroner’, starring Claire Goose. 
With its Victorian gothic features the house is ideal for a bit of murder and mystery’ says John Howell, owner of Lukesland. 
"We are really looking forward to seeing the episode on November 25," said John. 
The house is also open for a private tour by the owners on November 12 through the Invitation to View scheme.
